ol.li: Learn how to add and scale vectors in \R^n, both algebraically and geometrically.
Pictures: vector addition, vector subtraction, linear combinations.

subsection.title: Vectors in \R^n
subsection.p: We have been drawing points in \R^n as dots in the line, plane, space, etc. We can also draw them as arrows. Since we have two geometric interpretations in mind, we now discuss the relationship between the two points of view.
The difference is purely psychological: points and vectors are both just lists of numbers.

subsection.p: When we think of a point in \R^n as a vector, we will usually write it vertically, like a matrix with one column: v = \vec{1 3}. We will also write 0 for the zero vector. {1\choose 2}A vector 0The zero vector

bluebox.p: Unless otherwise specified, we will assume that all vectors start at the origin.

subsection.p: Vectors makes sense in the real world: many physical quantities, such as velocity, are represented as vectors. But it makes more sense to think of the velocity of a car as being located at the car.

remark.p: Some authors use boldface letters to represent vectors, as in \mathbf v, or use arrows, as in \oldvec v. As it is usually clear from context if a letter represents a vector, we do not decorate vectors in this way.

subsection.title: Vector Algebra and Geometry
subsection.p: Here we learn how to add vectors together and how to multiply vectors by numbers, both algebraically and geometrically.

statement.p:
We can add two vectors together: \vec{ a b c} + \vec{ x y z} = \vec{ a+x b+y c+z}. Vectoraddition
We can multiply, or scale, a vector by a real number c: Vectorscalar multiplication \def\r{\textcolor{red}} \r c\vec{ x y z} = \vec{ \r c\cdot x \r c\cdot y \r c\cdot z}. We call c a scalar to distinguish it from a vector. If v is a vector and c is a scalar, then cv is called a scalar multiple of v.
Addition and scalar multiplication work in the same way for vectors of length n.

subsection.title: Linear Combinations
subsection.p: We can add and scale vectors in the same equation.

statement.p:
Let c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_k be scalars, and let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k be vectors in \R^n. The vector in \R^n c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_kv_k
is called a linear combination of the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k, with weights or coefficients c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_k.

subsection.p: Geometrically, a linear combination is obtained by stretching / shrinking the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k according to the coefficients, then adding them together using the parallelogram law.
